title.narrative: AWESOME(Advancing Women's Engagement: Strengthening Opportunities to Mobilise for Equality)

description.narrative: A 5 year advocacy programme to support women's movements in Ethiopia,Kenya and Uganda to be strengthened, less, fragmented and more representative of diverse groups of women, including women with disabilities. These stronger women's movements will contribute to strong women leaders at all levels and the prevention and elimination of sexual and gender based violence (SGBV)

title.narrative: Increased collective advocacy efforts by women's rights organisation (WRO) actors for policy change and legal reform, national and regional level
Number of influencing spaces attended or facilitated related to SGBV and participation

description.narrative: Formal institutions outcome 3.02: Increase in level of implementation of existing SGBV laws and policies on women's rights (# of advocacy efforts)

comment.narrative:
There is a 50% implementation of existing SGBV laws and policies on women's rights. FIDA will measure the increase in implementation through the number of advocacy effors each year, for which the baseline is 0. Our baseline found slow uptake of the SGBV legislative framework.
In terms of what has already been done to support the cause, there have been consultative/ lobby meetings, policy dialogues with duty bearers and submissions of memos."

10 advocacy efforts by the end of AWESOME which will show increase in the level of implementation of existing SGBV laws and policies on women’s rights. In Year 2, the advocacy efforts will be about gender-responsive policy legistlations reviews. Advocacy efforts means activities like policy dialogues, consultative/lobby meetings with duty bearers, drafting and submissions of pettitions, policy briefs, memos and policy reviews

title.narrative: An increase in gender sensitive and disability inclusive coverage and reporting in the media
Number of media spots that promote women’s (including WwDs) rights

description.narrative: Society Outcome 2.07: # and type of media campaign actions launched

comment.narrative:
"Baseline indicator is zero as these are new media campaigns that will be developed under AWESOME. Women will actively participate in campaigns including social media, press statements.
Campaigns will be national, and most radio and TV can be accessed nationaly."
We hope to run 75 media campaigns (30 radio shows , 6 TV show, 6 webinars, and 30 road shows). These will lead to attitude change on community perception towards matters of SGBV.

title.narrative: An increase in the number and diversity of women supported with training, awareness raising, and networking

Number of women supported with training, awareness raising, and networking. (Note - we are tracking both the number of women supported with capacity, and the smaller number of those who then go onto actively engage in the women's movement (below). We can report either or both to the MFA, depending on your preference.)

description.narrative: Self outcome 1.04: Number of representatives (of women’s rights orgs) in each regional who are actively participating in the network and report feeling safe and included by the WRMs

comment.narrative:
"WROs from across the regions of Kenya are not currently adequately included in the nationwide movement.
This indicator will target 160 representatives from 80 WROs (who are involved in 8 regional forums, bringing together 10 WROs in each region of Nairobi, Nakuru, Garissa, Embu, Nyeri, Kakamega, Kisumu and Mombasa). These same individuals will be worked with during the 5 years of AWESOME."

By the end of AWESOME, the desired change is that 160 representatives are actively participating in their network, and report feeling safe and included with the women's rights movement (meaning WROs and community groups). Actively participating means regularly attending meetings.

The content of the capacity building initiatives: The forums brought together 80 WROs and 320 participants from the 8 provinces of Kenya. Participants were trained on feminism and feministic approaches. Mentors also participated in learning and experience sharing lessons. The WROs were selected based on their record of work on women’s leadership and participation and their work on the elimination of SGBV. The forums were intended for capacity building and creation of collaborative advocacy platforms to ensure accountability of duty bearers to commitments made on women’s leadership and the elimination of SGBV. Through these fora FIDA Kenya and partners successfully supported the bid for the first female Chief Justice. Some WROs recorded more than 2 anticipated participants

By the end of AWESOME, the desired change is that 160 representatives are actively participating in their network, and report feeling safe and included with the women's rights movement (meaning WROs and community groups). Actively participating means regularly attending meetings.
